preface.title: Release Notes
preface.para:
These release notes cover features and changes for:
SciDB Community Edition (CE)
SciDB Enterprise Edition (EE)
Paradigm4 Labs (P4Labs), which is a collection of external tools (such as SciDB-R) maintained in the form of GitHub repositories.

Note that we may deprecate some items but commit to providing advance notice about operators that may be removed in the next release. The items marked for deprecation below are present in R&scidb_version; but may be removed in the next release.

section.title: Supported Operating Systems
section.para: SciDB R&scidb_version; supports three platforms: Ubuntu 12.04, RHEL 6, and CentOS 6.

section.title: Community Edition Features and Changes
section.para:
This version includes the following features and changes:
The start-up process of SciDB is parallelized, so should be much faster than previous releases, especially if your cluster consists of many nodes.
The index_lookup() and uniq() operators have been optimized, and have officially become part of SciDB. They may be used as a workaround of non-integer dimensions, which are no longer supported. Refer to http://www.scidb.org/forum/viewtopic.php?f=18&t=1172 for details.
A new aggregate, prod(), has been added. It computes the product of a set of values.
In the create array statement, the 'immutable' constraint is no longer valid. Also, the 'not empty' constraint is deprecated.
The special value, NA, is no longer supported. You can use NaN or Null instead.
The semantics of aggregates involving NaN have been changed to return NaN, to maintain consistency with the IEEE standard.
The multiply() operator is no longer supported.
To multiply dense matrices, use the gemm() operator.
To multiply sparse matrices, use the spgemm() operator, which is available in the Enterprise Edition.
The redimension_store operator is deprecated. Use store(redimension()) instead.
The cross() operator is deprecated. Use cross_join() instead.
The build_sparse() operator is deprecated. Use store(redimension(build())) instead.
The special-case aggregate operators are deprecated. Use the more general aggregate() operator instead. These include the following:
approxdc()
avg()
count()
max()
min()
stdev()
sum()
var()
The semantics of unary operators over a missing value will be changed, to return null (a special case of missing value where the missing code is 0), in order to be consistent with the semantics of binary operators.

section.title: Enterprise Edition Features and Changes
section.para: This version includes the following features and changes:

listitem.para: The functions first() and last() have been renamed to first_index() and last_index(), respectively.
The operators cumsum() and cumprod() have been removed. Use the cumulate() operator instead.
The operators linregr() and logistregr() have been removed. Use the glm() operator instead.
The operator solve() has been removed. Use the glm() operator instead.

section.title: Paradigm4 Labs Features and Changes
section.para: We make available a collection of external tools in the form of GitHub repositories at http://github.com/paradigm4.

The following P4 Labs features have been added:
Loading files in the HDF-5 format is supported. For details, see https://github.com/Paradigm4/SciDB-HDF5.
Embedded R is supported. For details, see https://github.com/Paradigm4/r_exec.

listitem.para: The dimensions() operator sometimes reports incorrect start, length, low and high values for unbounded arrays. Correct values may be obtained using apply() to translate a dimension into an attribute, followed by a min / max aggregate.
The difference between the largest and the smallest dimension value in an array must not exceed (2^61 - 1).
The adddim() and deldim() operators may return incorrect results, or cause a system crash, when used in certain queries.
For operators gemm() and gesvd(), the chunks of the input must be square, and must have a chunk interval from 32 to 1024.

Whenever a query requires filtering on dimension values, the filter() operator performs slower than it needs to. In the vast majority of cases, between(), subarray(), cross_join(), or a combination of them, will substantially increase performance. For more information about using cross_join() as a dimensions filter, see the slides at http://www.scidb.org/forum/viewtopic.php?f=18&t=1204.
Using mixed-case names for databases is not recommended. Use all lowercase names to avoid problems.
